items.title: Problem with application launch
items.body:
I'm running into a problem where launching a frozen application from the command line on OSX results in the following error:

```
Fatal Python error: initfsencoding: unable to load the file system codec
ModuleNotFoundError: No module named 'encodings'
```

The error does **not** occur when the application is run on the original computer, but does occur when run on a clean machine.  I debugged, and the error is occurring at the following line of Console.c, in the InitializePython() function (the non-windows version):

```
    Py_Initialize();
```

Swapping in a Console file from an older version of cx-Freeze resolves the issue.

The issue may be related to the change in revision 8762f3e803 that reordered the code so that Py_Initialize is run before the module search path is set?

items.title: Matplotlib's mpl_toolkits raises TypeError
items.body:
After the patch in [this comment](https://github.com/marcelotduarte/cx_Freeze/issues/692#issuecomment-657125847), `mpl_toolkits` raises `TypeError` in function `_ReplacePathsInCode` of `finder.py` in this code

```
if searchValue == "*":
    searchValue = os.path.dirname(topLevelModule.file)
```
`topLevelModule.file` becomes `None`.

To fix that, use `'excludes': ['mpl_toolkits']` in the `build_exe`.

Also see this [comment](https://github.com/marcelotduarte/cx_Freeze/issues/696#issuecomment-662776313).

items.title: cx_Freeze 6.2 - TypeError dist must be a Distribution instance
items.body:
I've upgraded cx_Freeze from 6.1 to 6.2 in a project and now I got this error when running `python setup.py bdist_msi`:
```
TypeError dist must be a Distribution instance
```

This seems to be related to this warning:
```
UserWarning: Distutils was imported before Setuptools
```

Downgrading to 6.1 fixed the issues.

Environment:
* Python 3.6.8
* Windows 10

items.title: cx_Freeze 6.2 breaks matplotlib projects
items.body:

items.title: no module named encodings
items.body:
Packaged program crash with "no module named encodings".
because Py_SetPath(...) must be called before Py_Initialize() in InitializePython in Common.c

items.title: Please release a new version to PyPI
items.body:
The latest version on PyPI (6.1) doesn't really work because of issue #560 which was fixed by @anthony-tuininga in commit 4a24f1cdefe05c84c215c9f1b3694697e6ccab60 just 2 days after the release. But a fixed version was never uploaded to PyPI, so the latest "stable" official release has been broken for half a year now.

It would be nice if there were timely updates on PyPI once a critical bug has been found so that we're not always forced to use a locally built version from GitHub.

Hi, 

When I pack my obfuscated python program with cx_freeze I got the following error:

```
Fatal Python error: Py_Initialize: unable to load the file system codec
ModuleNotFoundError: No module named 'encodings'

Current thread 0x00001718 (most recent call first):
```

I am using ```cx_freeze 6.2``` with ```Python 3.6.10 :: Anaconda, Inc.```

Then I tried with ```cx_freeze 6.2``` and ```Python 3.7.7``` then got the following error:

```
Fatal Python error: initfsencoding: unable to load the file system codec
ModuleNotFoundError: No module named 'encodings'

Current thread 0x000050d8 (most recent call first):
```
This was not happening until I added pythonnet(clr) package to program. Here is my setup.py:
```
import sys
from cx_Freeze import setup, Executable

base = None
# Normally packages are found automatically but since we obfuscate the code cx_freeze can not find them automatically

    version="0.0.1",
    description="Prelim App Rest Server",

)
```

items.title: Application runs only one time and then it cannot find a package
items.body:
Hello Guys,
I have created a small app with Tkinter that allows to extract some data from selected Excel files and create a nice report. I want to share it with my colleagues. Thus, I decided to create an "exe" file out of my code. 
After building the app with the following "setup" file:

`from cx_Freeze import setup, Executable
import cx_Freeze as cx
import sys
import os

libs_to_include = ["tkinter","os",'csv',"pandas","xlwings","xlsxwriter","numpy","matplotlib.backends.backend_tkagg",
            "scipy.sparse.csgraph._validation","scipy"]

packages_to_include = ["tw_package"] + libs_to_include
libs_to_exclude = ['PyQt4', 'PyQt5', 'PySide', 'IPython','jupyter_client', 'jupyter_core', 'ipykernel','ipython_genutils',"scipy.spatial.cKDTree"]

include_files = [r"tw_package\resources"]
if platform.system() == "Windows":
    base = "Win32GUI"
    target_name = 'tw_app.exe'
    PYTHON_DIR = os.path.dirname(os.path.dirname(os.__file__))
    os.environ['TCL_LIBRARY'] = os.path.join(PYTHON_DIR, 'tcl', 'tcl8.6')
    os.environ['TK_LIBRARY'] = os.path.join(PYTHON_DIR, 'tcl', 'tk8.6')
    include_files += [
        (os.path.join(PYTHON_DIR, 'DLLs', 'tcl86t.dll'), ''),
        (os.path.join(PYTHON_DIR, 'DLLs', 'tk86t.dll'), '')
    ]



cx.setup(
    name='Tw_App',
    version='1.4',
    author='Teodor Wisniewski',
    description='Data driven applicatios',
    packages=['tw_package'],
    executables=[
        cx.Executable('main_app.py', base=base,
                      targetName=target_name)],
    options={
        'build_exe': {
            'packages': packages_to_include,
            'includes': libs_to_include,
            'excludes': libs_to_exclude,
            'include_files': include_files
        }
    }
)`

I can open my application one time and it works as I want, but as I relaunch the app, I get the following error:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/48416342/80359640-63369600-887e-11ea-86c1-aa90bd644328.png)

Here is the structure of my project:

- main_app.py
- setup.py
- tw_package 
In the tw_package, there are other sub packages.

Do you have any ideas why my app cannot find this package? It works if I open it in my IDE.

items.title: Error importing .so file when pyproj is installed
items.body:
Hello,

I have an application that mainly uses `pyproj` lib.
After running the `python setup.py build_exe` and running the frozen bin I get the following error:

```python
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/home/rodrigo/programations/misc/test-cx_freeze/.venv/lib/python3.6/site-packages/cx_Freeze/initscripts/__startup__.py", line 40, in run
    module.run()
  File "/home/rodrigo/programations/misc/test-cx_freeze/.venv/lib/python3.6/site-packages/cx_Freeze/initscripts/Console.py", line 37, in run
    exec(code, {'__name__': '__main__'})
  File "app.py", line 2, in <module>
    import pyproj
  File "/home/rodrigo/programations/misc/test-cx_freeze/.venv/lib/python3.6/site-packages/pyproj/__init__.py", line 51, in <module>
    from pyproj import _datadir
ImportError: libproj-9e402c09.so.15.3.1: cannot open shared object file: No such file or directory
```

One strange thing (that I don't know if is intended or not) is that the `__startup__.py` file being used for initializing the application is in my virtualenv:
 `"[...]/test-cx_freeze/.venv/lib/python3.6/site-packages/cx_Freeze/initscripts/__startup__.py"`

Furthermore, when I ran the `find` command into the build folder, I get the following response:
```bash
find build/ -name "libproj-9e402c09.so.15.3.1"
build/lib/pyproj/libproj-9e402c09.so.15.3.1
```
So it looks like that the `.so` file exists inside the `build/lib/` folder.

I don't know if I'm missing some configuration, or anything else. Any help is greatly appreciated!

#### Using:
* Python 3.6.9
* OS: Ubuntu 18.04.4 LTS
* cx-freeze: 6.1
* pyproj: 2.6.0

#### Files for replicating the problem:
##### setup.py
```python
# setup.py
from cx_Freeze import setup, Executable

BUILD_PATH = "build/"

ENTRY_SCRIPT_NAME = "app.py"
TARGET_NAME = "test_freeze"

# Setup base packages
build_exe_options = {
    "packages": [
        "pyproj",
    ],
}

# Defines the executable for the app
EXECUTABLES = [
    Executable(
        ENTRY_SCRIPT_NAME,
        targetName=TARGET_NAME,
    )
]

setup(
    name="TestFreeze",
    version="0.0.1",
    description="Test Freeze",
    options={
        "build": {
            "build_exe": BUILD_PATH,
        },
        "build_exe": build_exe_options
    },
    executables=EXECUTABLES
)

```

##### app.py
```python
# app.py

import pyproj


def main():
    print(pyproj.__version__)


if __name__ == '__main__':
    main()
```
#### Commands used for setting up the project:
```bash
# inside a virtualenv
pip install pyproj cx-freeze
python setup.py build_exe
./build/test_freeze
```

### Edit 1:

So, I was fiddling around with the `pyproj` version and I discovered that downgrading the version to `2.5.0` fixed the problem.

For now this is a solution, but I think that is far from optimal. Is there a way to discover what the differences are between the `2.6.0` and `2.5.0` of the `pyproj` lib for finding a more permanent solution?

items.title: add_to_path seems to require all_users
items.body: When building an msi with the new cx_Freeze 6.1, which now has all_users set to False by default, the installation fails with insufficient priviliges to adapt the PATH enironment variable. A better solution would be to add to the users PATH or at least ask for privilege elevation.

items.title: issue with VersionInfo
items.body:
Using Tendo and the build gets the error: [screenshot](https://prnt.sc/r29pxg)
Using cx_freeeze 6.1.
Issues is with these lines:
```
_v = VersionInfo('tendo').semantic_version()
__version__ = _v.release_string()
version_info = _v.version_tuple()
```
Commenting these lines out seems to fix the issue.

```python
executables = [Executable("spleng.py", base=base, icon='./qt/spleng.ico')]
```

items.title: Installing a Win32Service gives AttributeError: module '__main__' has no attribute 'NAME'
items.body:
Hi,
I have built cx_Freeze 6.0 with Python 3.7.5, cx_Logging 2.2, Visual Studio 2019 on Windows 10 and have managed to get a `Win32Service.exe` in the `bases` directory.
I then built the provided sample under `samples/service`, but when I run the created executable with
```cmd
build\exe.win-amd64-3.7\cx_FreezeSampleService.exe --install test
```
I get the error
```
Service not installed. See log file for details.
```
and the following log file:
```
[20580] 2019/12/06 08:09:43.120 starting logging at level ERROR
[20580] 2019/12/06 08:09:43.134 Python exception encountered:
[20580] 2019/12/06 08:09:43.134     Internal Message: cannot locate service name
[20580] 2019/12/06 08:09:43.134     Type => <class 'AttributeError'>
[20580] 2019/12/06 08:09:43.135     Value => module '__main__' has no attribute 'NAME'
[20580] 2019/12/06 08:09:43.142     AttributeError: module '__main__' has no attribute 'NAME'

[20580] 2019/12/06 08:09:43.154 ending logging
```
It seems like the global variables in `Config.py` like `NAME` etc. are somehow not recognized as attributes of the `__main__` module.
I managed to get it working by explicitly adding the variables to the `__main__` module in `Config.py` like this
```python
import sys
sys.modules[__name__].NAME = 'cx_FreezeSampleService%s'
sys.modules[__name__].DISPLAY_NAME = 'cx_Freeze Sample Service - %s'
sys.modules[__name__].MODULE_NAME = 'ServiceHandler'
sys.modules[__name__].CLASS_NAME = 'Handler'
sys.modules[__name__].DESCRIPTION = 'Sample service description'
sys.modules[__name__].AUTO_START = False
sys.modules[__name__].SESSION_CHANGES = False
```
Perhaps there is something that can be changed in `Win32Service.c` instead of this inelegant workaround, but I have not enough knowledge about the Python C API to understand what is going on.

items.title: App with wxPython doesn't work
items.body: I have some different apps with wxPython. There were no problems with the previous beta version of 6.0. But after I updated to the newest 6.0 version the freezed apps doesn't work anymore. I got the following error ... see the first snapshot. In the second snapshot you can see the comparison of the lib-folders (6.0beta and latest 6.0). It seems there is a difference of the naming in the dll-files (.pyd) of wxPython. On the newest version the wxPython dll-files include the text `.cp37-win_amd64`. Maybe this breaks the execution of the app. ![Screenshot_2019-10-25_12-08-22](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/24735031/67563359-cd7c4b80-f720-11e9-807f-3d2208ca4ff6.png) I work on Windows 10 with Python 3.7.4 and wxPython 4.0.6.

items.title: sqlite3.dll not always in DLLs folder
items.body:
In Anaconda3 distributions, the sqlite3.dll is not in the `DLLs` folder, but in `Library/bin`.  As per issue #207, I modified hooks.py, load_sqlite3() as shown below to successfully load the dll from the Anaconda location.
```
def load_sqlite3(finder, module):
    """In Windows, the sqlite3 module requires an additional dll sqlite3.dll to
       be present in the build directory."""
    if sys.platform == "win32":
        dll_name = "sqlite3.dll"
        dll_path = os.path.join(sys.base_prefix, "DLLs", dll_name)
        lib_path = os.path.join(sys.base_prefix, "Library", "bin", dll_name)
        if os.path.exists(dll_path):
            finder.IncludeFiles(dll_path, os.path.join("lib", dll_name))
        else:
            finder.IncludeFiles(lib_path, os.path.join("lib", dll_name))
```

items.title: ImportError: bad magic number
items.body:
Using cx_Freeze from PyPI (6.0) and Python 3.6.8 from a (mini)conda environment, after freezing I get the error

```

```

I did some research and it seems that the Python versions are off.
From within the target Python env it gives the expected magic number

```
>>> import importlib.util
>>> importlib.util.MAGIC_NUMBER
b'3\r\r\n'
```

Any ideas on how to debug this further?

items.title: libffi-7.dll is not grabbed for projects using ctypes module on Python 3.8
items.body:
**Environment**: Windows

**Steps**:
1) download the project https://github.com/t-o-n-y-p/rssim/tree/4e21c9e9cbe23cc3f7eefc4ee876608b6db5aa9d and install all the requirements
2) patch the implementation of nullterm method in win32verstamp.py 
```
def nullterm(s):
  # get raw bytes for a NULL terminated unicode string.
  if sys.version_info[:2] < (3, 8):
    return (str(s) + '\0').encode('unicode-internal')
  else:
    return (str(s) + '\0').encode('utf-16le')
```
3) run `python setup.py build`

**Result**:
After freezing my project on Python 3.8, libffi-7.dll is missing in /lib folder, and that's what I get when launching the exe:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/42129780/67045247-f445eb00-f13e-11e9-9ce7-5a8804491435.png)
The workaround is to copy this file manually.

Works fine on Python 3.7.5.

items.title: gestalt is a python module and should not be excluded by default
items.body:
currently gestalt is in the initial exclude list in hooks.py if not a mac device. However, there is a python package with this name, resulting in module not found error

https://pypi.org/project/gestalt/

remove from hooks.py or allow overriding this list if specified in the requires/packages fields

items.title: cx_Freeze looks for non-existent sqlite3.dll in virtualenv's DLLs directory in winodws
items.body: Using Python 3.6 and cx-Freeze v6.0b1, `build_exe` fails because cx-freeze is looking for `sqlite3.dll` inside the (non-existent) `DLLs` directory inside the virtual environment from which it was invoked. If I copy the `sqlite3.dll` file into newly created `DLLs` inside my virtual environment folder, the build is successful.

items.title: Win32Service.exe base doesn't get built
items.body:
When you build 6.0 the Win32Service.exe base doesn't get built, it's just silently ignored. You need to have cx_Logging available - not installed but a built distribution in a parallel directory without the version number (i.e. "cx_Logging" not "cx_Logging-2.2")

Also, the cx_Logging 2.2 tar ball is missing the cx_Logging.h so it doesn't build. I had to pull that from GitHub and drop it into cx_Logging\src

Finally, the cx_Freeze build will still fail if cx_Logging.h isn't also put into the root of cx_Logging!

Since cx_Logging hasn't changed in years could it not be included in the cx_Freeze tar ball so you can build Win32Service.exe without so much pain!?

```
TypeError: startswith first arg must be str or a tuple of str, not NoneType
```

The _site_packages_dirs in TensorFlow 1.14 keeps paths to Pythons Lib\site-packages.
On TensorFlow 1.13.1 after freezing my project works.

items.title: -l gcov required on arm platform
items.body:
Hi,

I tried to build cx_freeze 5.0.2 on two different arm based devices and had the following error on running "python setup.py install"

Output: https://pastebin.com/TYpZuFy0

The tested systems were:

> Debian 6.0.10
> armv5tel
> Linux 3.8.13 #12
> gcc version 4.4.5 (Debian 4.4.5-8)
> Python 3.6.8

> Debian 9.6
> armv7l
> Linux 4.4.153-mvebu #36
> gcc version 6.3.0 20170516 (Debian 6.3.0-18+deb9u1)
> Python 3.6.8

To get around this problem I had to add an `extraArgs` entry on line 98 in setup.py

`extraArgs.append("-lgcov")`

After that the build process worked fine. I also tried this on x86 systems but they worked without this change.

I am not very deep in C so I dont know the exact effects on this. Maybe someone can have a look on this.

Best regards

JonasR

The output below shows the sample code that isolates the issue. When executing this file from Python, there is no problem and everything works as expected.
```
marc@ubuntu:/tmp/test$ cat helloworld.py 
from cryptography.fernet import Fernet

print ('Hello world')
marc@ubuntu:/tmp/test$ python3 helloworld.py 
Hello world
```
Next, I proceed to freeze the application with cxfreeze, as follows:

my problem goes as follows, when I run my cx_Freeze script I get this message in command prompt:

But i can clearly find this file and it is located under:

So I have no idea what to do, I am newbie when it comes to this cx_Freeze stuff and all I wanted to do was show my friends who aren't into programming my new PyOpenGL game I made!

So appreciate if anybody has any solutions or suggestions to this problem.
